Authors: Eghbali A.; Ikonen E.; Karha P.
Author full names: Eghbali, Afsaneh (58850613900); Ikonen, Erkki (7005924077); Karha, Petri (6602761978)
Title: Differential Spectral Responsivity of Solar Cells Measured with an LED Based Experimental Setup
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Metrology Research Institute, Aalto University, Espoo, 02150, Finland; Vtt Mikes, Espoo, 02150, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Eghbali A., Metrology Research Institute, Aalto University, Espoo, 02150, Finland; Ikonen E., Metrology Research Institute, Aalto University, Espoo, 02150, Finland, Vtt Mikes, Espoo, 02150, Finland; Karha P., Metrology Research Institute, Aalto University, Espoo, 02150, Finland
Abstract: We have developed an experimental setup for measuring differential spectral responsivities of solar cells under bias light conditions. Instead of the commonly used monochromator light source, our setup uses 30 high-brightness LEDs as a tunable quasi-monochromatic light source covering the wavelength range of 290 - 1300 nm. Halogen lamps are used to generate bifacial bias-lighting conditions resembling the spectrum of AM1.5G. The setup has been fully characterized for spectral irradiances and spatial uniformities of all light sources. Validation measurements carried out using a reference cell of 2×2 cm2 area from Fraunhofer ISE demonstrated an agreement better than 2% over the wavelength range of 425 - 940 nm, with an expanded uncertainty of 2.6%. In the UV and IR regions, the discrepancies are higher but still within estimated uncertainties. The setup is being employed as a reference in an interlaboratory comparison of indoor solar cells based on emerging technologies. A reference cell, an Epishine organic indoor cell, and a Panasonic amorphous silicon indoor cell are distributed among participants and measured for various parameters including short circuit current. We tested a method for deriving the reference values for short circuit currents mathematically from the differential spectral responsivities of the cells. The preliminary results shown indicate that the developed setup is feasible for measurements and calibrations of indoor solar cells.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Al-Thani H.A.; Hasoon F.S.
Author full names: Al-Thani, Hamda A. (6603429625); Hasoon, Falah S. (35546363900)
Title: Comprehensive Investigation on the Effect of Mo Back Contact Microstructural Properties on the CIGS Thin Film Microstructural Properties and Device Performance
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: National Energy and Water Research Center (NEWRC), P.O. Box 54111, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Al-Thani H.A., National Energy and Water Research Center (NEWRC), P.O. Box 54111, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates; Hasoon F.S., National Energy and Water Research Center (NEWRC), P.O. Box 54111, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Cu(In, Ga)Se2 (CIGS) thin films were deposited using 3-stage co-evaporation process, on five different series of Molybdenum (Mo) coated sodalime glass (SLG) substrates. The sputtering process the Mo films was carried out at different working gas (Ar) pressure of 0.6, 2.0, 5.0, 8.0, and 12.0 mTorr using direct-current (DC) planar magnetron and at fixed sputtering power density. Whereas, the co-evaporation process of all CIGS thin films was carried out at fixed conditions of deposition rates and substrate temperature. The variation in Mo sputtering pressure is intended in this research work to influence the amount of Na out-diffused from SLG substrate to CIGS film during the growth process. High-resolution field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was used to examine the morphology of both the Mo-coated SLG and the as-deposited CIGS thin films. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to examine the film microstructure such as preferred grain orientation in Mo and CIGS films and residual intrinsic stress in the Mo films. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was applied to measure the root-mean-square (RMS) surface roughness of the CIGS thin films. Also, Na out-diffusion through as-sputtered Mo and as-deposited CIGS thin films was depth profiled using secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). Furthermore, the performance of the CIGS complete devices was evaluated under standard conditions of 1000 W/m2 and 25°C.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Zaka A.; Alhassan S.; Nayfeh A.
Author full names: Zaka, Awais (57211556816); Alhassan, Saeed (36672479200); Nayfeh, Ammar (8610846300)
Title: RF-Powered Sputtering of Iron Pyrite for Photovoltaic Applications
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Khalifa University, Abu Dhabi, 127788, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Zaka A., Khalifa University, Abu Dhabi, 127788, United Arab Emirates; Alhassan S., Khalifa University, Abu Dhabi, 127788, United Arab Emirates; Nayfeh A., Khalifa University, Abu Dhabi, 127788, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: In the current study, two-dimensional FeS2 thin films were produced on a variety of substrates using a plasma-assisted, radio frequency (RF)-powered sputtering process. The purpose of this work was to investigate the suitability of these films for use in photovoltaic applications. A variety of methods were utilized in order to describe the FeS2 films. Solar applications were then evaluated using the thin films in their produced state. Pyrite films had outstanding absorption in the UV/Vis range, and calculations using the Tauc's plot indicated a broad band gap of approximately 2.25 eV. The construction and examination of solar devices revealed increased current production when exposed to sun conditions, indicating that the material is acceptable for use in photovoltaics.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Ali T.A.; Alzarooni K.; Alzarooni M.
Author full names: Ali, Turki Al (58850707200); Alzarooni, Khuloud (58850473900); Alzarooni, Muhra (58850394700)
Title: Solar Resource Management Towards 100% Renewable Electricity
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Ali T.A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alzarooni K., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alzarooni M., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: With the focus on the difficulties experienced by regions with high photovoltaic (PV) in their network and markets, the research examines the technologies, concepts, and regulations that enable the integration of 100% renewable energy. The potential balancing area for grid integration strategies is for the conventional electricity grid at a regional or national level. The focus is on integrating significant amounts of solar energy into the overall energy portfolio of a specific region or country. The research addresses the issues of energy transition and the requirement for solutions to integration problems. The goal of the research was to determine which resource management tactics were most advantageous. The approach included examining new grid integration technologies, assessing the efficacy of the current laws and regulations, and observing how solar resources management affected the potential of PV installations. The research utilized the literature review approach to analyze and synthesize relevant research articles, reports, and policy documents. It included interdisciplinary studies that explored the synergies between various PV systems and solar resources, energy storage, advance transmission concepts, demand management systems and solar-to-fuel and other high-embodied energy products. The research discovered the several concepts, technologies and policies that could enable the integration of 100% renewable electricity. These included energy storage, demand response, smart grid technologies, and policies that encourage the use of renewable energy sources. In addition, the significance of managing solar resources in maximizing the potential of PV systems was noted in the research. The research's key findings are that using the suggested technologies, concepts, and policies will make integrating 100% of renewable power possible. The paper advises the execution of a thorough strategy for resource management, which combines a number of the identified tactics and is adapted to the unique traits and difficulties of the various areas. The study acknowledges the limitation of the review, such as the lack of empirical data and the limited scope of the analyzed studies. Further research is recommended to investigate the economic, social, and environmental impacts of the identified strategies and their scalability of different regions.  © 2023 IEEE.

Title: Unilateral facial nerve paralysis induced changes in DMN functional connectivity; A fMRI study
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Deptart, Kyung Hee University, Youngin, South Korea; Korea Institute of Oriental Medicine (KIOM), Daejeon, South Korea; Department of Acupuncture and Moxibustion, School of Oriental Medicine, Kyunghee University, Seoul, South Korea; Department of Radiology, Kyunghee University, South Korea

Abstract: Bell's palsy (BP) is a common peripheral idiopathic disease affecting the facial nerve (CN VII) causing inability to move facial muscles on the affected side. We investigated BP's effects on the resting state default mode network (DMN) connectivity. Functional MRI was applied to 20 healthy volunteers and 31 BP patients at different stages with resting state. Patient's stages were defined based on disease duration and House-Brackmann Score. Dual regression approach was used for ICA based functional connectivity analysis to investigate DMN connectivity changes during different disease stages. All right sided BP patients' brain maps were flipped so that right brain hemisphere represents lesion side of the brain. It was found in this study that BP induced different brain connectivity changes within DMN varied between different stages. © 2014 IEEE.

Title: Illuminating Possibilities: A Comprehensive Review of Concentrating Solar Technologies for Sustainable Energy Solutions
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Alkhalid A., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Baha A., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Sasidharan A., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Louis J.D., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Abbas M., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Uyoh N., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Francis W.-E.O., Cranfield University, Bedfordshire, Cranfield, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A comprehensive review of existing Concentrated Solar (CS) technologies is carried out with a focus on identifying the most promising technologies for small and medium scale applications in the UK. The applications considered include domestic water heating, solar cooking, hydrogen production, plastic recycling and space cooling. Technical feasibility is evaluated, including factors such as site suitability, resource availability, and engineering requirements. The regulatory environment and policy framework in the UK with respect to renewable energy is also assessed to determine how Concentrating Solar can fit within this context[2]. Our findings suggests that the UK has moderate potential for concentrating solar applications, with low concentrating photovoltaics (LCPV) having the highest prospects. The best locations for these technologies are all situated in the southern parts of the UK. Potential barriers and challenges to the adoption of concentrated solar in the UK, such as space requirements, lack of awareness, and public acceptance are identified, and recommendations for addressing these issues are provided.  © 2023 IEEE.

Title: A model-guided peri-operative information systems approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Research Group Computer Assisted Medicine (CaMed), Dept. of Informatics, Reutlingen University, Reutlingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Burgert O., Research Group Computer Assisted Medicine (CaMed), Dept. of Informatics, Reutlingen University, Reutlingen, Germany; Fink E., Research Group Computer Assisted Medicine (CaMed), Dept. of Informatics, Reutlingen University, Reutlingen, Germany; Wiemuth M., Research Group Computer Assisted Medicine (CaMed), Dept. of Informatics, Reutlingen University, Reutlingen, Germany; Thies C., Research Group Computer Assisted Medicine (CaMed), Dept. of Informatics, Reutlingen University, Reutlingen, Germany
Abstract: Model-guided Therapy and Surgical Workflow Systems are two interrelated research fields, which have been developed separately in the last years. To make full use of both technologies, it is necessary to integrate them and connect them to Hospital Information Systems. We propose a framework for integration of Model-guided Therapy in Hospital Information Systems based on the Electronic Medical Record, and a task-based Workflow Management System, which is suitable for clinical end users. Two prototypes - one based on Business Process Modeling Language, one based on the scrum-board - are presented. From the experience with these prototypes, we developed a novel personalized visualization system for Surgical Workflows and Model-guided Therapy. Key challenges for further development are automated situation detection and a common communication infrastructure. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Riad M.
Author full names: Riad, Micheal (58850688100)
Title: Assessment of Cooling Effectiveness in Power Yields of a Multi-Orientational BIPV Façade of a High-Rise Building in a Hot and Arid Region: The Octagonal Tower
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Mrfs Power Building Contracting, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Riad M., Mrfs Power Building Contracting, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The study presented in this paper is a multi-simulation of a project created by the author called 'The Octagonal Tower,' an imaginary Office/Hotel tower in Dubai with façades facing eight orientations. The research objectives are to determine the energy yields and power generation of the BIPV system installed to each façade orientation and evaluate the losses due to increasing modules' temperature and the electric power gains from simulating different cooling levels for the BIPV systems. The reasoning of this analysis is due to the difference in the direct and diffused irradiance levels for each orientation at different times of the day, seasonal changes, as well as the different incidence angles and sun path. The different times each orientation receives the solar irradiance combined with the ambient temperature, wind speed, and other meteorological conditions significantly affect the power output and the modules' temperatures. The results assessed the arrays' temperature, power yields, and cooling effectiveness in the power gains for each façade orientation. Each orientation has its unique thermal behavior, which is important for identifying the cooling requirements compared with the potential gains. The average total gain of (13.86 %) was achieved by simulating cooling, with the South/West (17.7 %) at the highest gains, followed by South/East (17.3 %), and last is the North (3.9%). In three months, the North orientation and sub-orientations achieved higher power generation than the South. The South/East and South/West have higher power yields than the South. Cooling management of BIPV in summer is much more applicable than in winter; this will be described in the findings of this study.  © 2023 IEEE.

Author full names: Zaccari, Irene (36476835000); Davies, A Giles (56911604400); Walti, Christoph (6603826996); Laurenson, Sophie X. (23486071800)
Title: Label-free electrochemical biosensors for clinical diagnostic
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: University of Leeds, School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Abbott GmbH and Co, Max Planck Ring 2, Wiesbaden, 65205, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Zaccari I., University of Leeds, School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Davies A.G., University of Leeds, School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Walti C., University of Leeds, School of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds, LS2 9JT, United Kingdom; Laurenson S.X., Abbott GmbH and Co, Max Planck Ring 2, Wiesbaden, 65205, Germany
Abstract: We present the development of a high sensitivity, label-free, biosensor platform suitable for multiplexed point-of-care diagnostics. A sensor surface based on a carboxy-terminated oligo ethylene-glycol (OEG) self-assembled monolayer (SAM) was developed and fully characterised. Optimal conditions for antibody immobilisation were found for a buffer pH approximately one unit below the pI of the antibody, which yielded both higher antibody density on the sensor surface as well as higher sensor response to the antigen. At the same time the surface showed good resistance to non-specific adsorption of high concentrations of proteins. A non-faradaic electrochemical impedance spectroscopy biosensor to detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in full serum was demonstrated as a proof of concept. By using the phase of the impedance at 100 mHz as the sensor response, a linear relationship of the phase shift vs the logarithm of hCG concentration was established between 26 fM and 0.26 nM with a sensitivity of 0.6 degree per decade, which is a significant improvement over current state-of-the-art biosensor systems. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors with affiliations: Aly S.P., Research and Development Center, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Chapaneri K., Research and Development Center, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; John J.J., Research and Development Center, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mathiak G., Research and Development Center, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alarm M.A., Purdue University, Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, West Lafayette, IN, United States
Abstract: One of the most common approaches to estimate the photovoltaic parameters under varying environmental conditions is to first extract these parameters at a reference condition, usually at standard test conditions (STC). The temperature and irradiance dependance of each of these STC parameters is then calculated using a set of translation equations. Although the translation equations are based on device physics, the biggest disadvantage of this approach is that the constants in the translation equations are not universal for different photovoltaic technologies. To address this limitation, a unified fitting approach has been proposed, which not only extracts the five photovoltaic parameters but also adjusts the constants of the translation equations. The proposed method exhibits a marked improvement in the fitting accuracy for the measured I-V curves of the module.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Nader A.; Eldeib A.M.
Author full names: Nader, Ashraf (56522758600); Eldeib, Ayman M. (6507588870)
Title: A novel approach for remote diagnosis and troubleshooting for lab instruments
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Nader A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Eldeib A.M., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Abstract: The use of remote diagnosis and troubleshooting are widely used nowadays to improve instruments' uptime and minimize workflow interruption. However, such feature is not used in many critical care units and/or laboratories either due to limited capabilities and access offered by manufacturers of such equipment or because of high cost for interface software packages especially for developing countries. The negative impact is more felt in laboratories with old instruments lacking remote connection ports but having an embedded maintenance and/or troubleshooting software. This paper describes a direct access remote diagnosis and troubleshooting for the input and output devices of a critical care and laboratory instrument using a flat data cable, an 8 cm × 10 cm built-in printed circuit board designed for this purpose, a standard parallel cable, and a control software. The main advantage of this approach is its low cost, compact design and simple implementation besides being convenient and suitable for other instruments possessing input/output devices with the same specifications. Implementation of the software and hardware related to accessing the instrument's membrane keypad and display using a PC has been successfully accomplished and tested leading to the use of all PC communication capabilities including remote connection and access. By integrating all hardware components, the prototype system was capable of remotely diagnosing and controlling the instrument on real-time basis. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Critical care instruments; direct remote access; laboratory equipment; remote diagnosis; troubleshooting

Title: Intelligent classification of real heart diseases based on radial wavelet neural network

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a radial wavelet neural network classifier for heart murmurs (pulmonary insufficiency and tricuspid insufficiency). The extended Kalman filter is used as a learning algorithm. The network inputs are dimensional features, extracted from real cardiac cycles. The proposed model is trained and tested using real heart cycles in order to show the applicability of the proposed scheme. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Alheloo A.; Almheiri A.; Kumar S.; Mathiak G.; Alberts V.
Author full names: Alheloo, Ahmad (57221602504); Almheiri, Ali (57221600698); Kumar, Sagarika (57203425925); Mathiak, Gerhard (57277706300); Alberts, Vivian (57278314200)
Title: Characterization and Analysis of PV Module Defects and Degradation Mechanisms through Use of Module External Quantum Efficiency
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Alheloo A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Almheiri A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Kumar S., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mathiak G., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alberts V., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: This paper proposes a module-level external quantum efficiency (m-EQE) technique to analyze optical losses in photovoltaic (PV) modules caused by common degradation mechanisms and defects. The effectiveness of m-EQE is compared to conventional methods such as illuminated IV and UV-F imaging. Measurements of m-EQE, IV, and UV-F are taken on three different modules, two exposed to a desert climate for seven years and one kept indoors. The analysis shows that the aged modules experience a decline in performance, particularly at lower wavelengths as correlated by m-EQE, which corresponds to the UV-F degradation patterns observed. The m-EQE technique has proven to provide an edge in defects analysis and is an easy-to-use, verifiable, and standardizable method for analyzing module-level optical losses.  © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Degradation; Quantum efficiency; Solar panels; Conventional methods; Defect mechanisms; Degradation mechanism; Degradation patterns; Desert climates; Exposed to; External quantum efficiency; Measurements of; Performance; Photovoltaic modules; Defects

Title: Content based modified reaction-diffusion equation for modeling tumor growth of low grade glioma
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Research Lab for Medical Imaging and Digital Surgery, Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, University Town of Shenzhen, 1068 Xueyuan Boulevard, Xili Nanshan, 518055, China; Shenzhen College of Advanced Technology, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Faculty of Computers and Informations, Masnoura University, Mansoura city, Egypt

Abstract: This paper presents a content based modified reaction diffusion (RD) equation for modeling glioma growth. The reaction diffusion equation is modified by a weighted parameter that measures the white matter proportion in a small window. Given two MRI time-points scans of the same patient, the manually segmented tumor of the first scan is used as an initial seed to the proposed method while the second scan is used as the ground truth to measure the accuracy of the simulated results. For healthy tissues segmentation around the initial seed, spatial fuzzy C-means algorithm that accounts for neighborhood information of the image is used. As a proof of concept, the proposed method is tested on one low grade glioma case with 7 month difference between the two scans. The preliminary results of the modified RD equation show higher accuracy as compared with the standard RD equation. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Matharani K.; Jariwala H.
Author full names: Matharani, Kinnari (58126271200); Jariwala, Hitesh (56600549500)
Title: Washout Filter-Based Droop Control for Solar PV Based Microgrid
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Svnit, Electrical Engineering Department, Surat, India
Authors with affiliations: Matharani K., Svnit, Electrical Engineering Department, Surat, India; Jariwala H., Svnit, Electrical Engineering Department, Surat, India
Abstract: This paper introduces a washout filter-based droop control system for a solar Photo voltaic (PV) microgrid. The droop control mechanism efficiently manages the microgrid's output power by monitoring and controlling its frequency and voltage. Unlike the conventional droop control method, the proposed control approach acknowledges the deviations in frequency and voltage during steady-state operation. In response to these deviations, the suggested controller takes action autonomously, without relying on communication lines, to restore the system to its nominal frequency and voltage levels. The proposed approach's efficacy is verified by executing a comprehensive simulation using MATLAB/Simulink. Two distinct scenarios are explored: one involving a step change in load for different droop gains and the other a variation in solar insolation levels. The simulation results are compared with a conventional droop to see the efficacy of the proposed approach. The proposed controller's superiority is demonstrated by its adeptness in restoring frequency and voltage while ensuring equitable power sharing among DGs for different droop coefficients.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Alkhalidi A.; Boretti A.; Owhaib W.; Salameh T.; Hader M.; Al-Kouz W.
Author full names: Alkhalidi, Ammar (36102248600); Boretti, Alberto (57208229418); Owhaib, Wahib (6507145995); Salameh, Tareq (36657654000); Hader, Montasir (7003849669); Al-Kouz, Wael (36080512500)
Title: Design of a Solar CSP Plant for Ma'an, Jordan
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Sharjah, Sustainable and Renewable, Engineering Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Jordan University of Science and Technology, Aeronautical Engineering Department, Irbid, Jordan; German Jordanian University, Mechanical and Maintenance Engineering Department, Amman, Jordan; University of North Alabama, Department of Engineering and Industrial Professions, Florence, 35632, AL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Alkhalidi A., University of Sharjah, Sustainable and Renewable, Engineering Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Boretti A., Jordan University of Science and Technology, Aeronautical Engineering Department, Irbid, Jordan; Owhaib W., German Jordanian University, Mechanical and Maintenance Engineering Department, Amman, Jordan; Salameh T., University of Sharjah, Sustainable and Renewable, Engineering Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Hader M., Jordan University of Science and Technology, Aeronautical Engineering Department, Irbid, Jordan; Al-Kouz W., University of North Alabama, Department of Engineering and Industrial Professions, Florence, 35632, AL, United States
Abstract: Solar CSP is a great method for electrical generation, especially in Ma'an as it has a very high solar irradiance. The manuscript investigate the proper design of a concentrated solar power plant for Maan, Jordan, a location of excellent solar resource. SAM simulation software was used for power output estimation. The result showed that the annual average capacity factor is 91.4% thanks to the oversizing of the solar field and the thermal energy storage by molten salt. The economic feasibility of this power plant was investigated by considering a lifetime of 30 years, the LCOE was found to be 7.41 c/kWh. Opposite to solar PV, electricity is produced over most of the day and not only during daylight time, thus necessitating limited external storage or energy supply by fully dispatchable conventional sources to be integrated into a grid.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Sugimoto H.
Author full names: Sugimoto, Hiroki (35367123100)
Title: Feasibility Study of Rechargeable Flexible Tandem Solar Cells for VIPV Applications Under Realistic Environments
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Pxp Corporation, Kanagawa, Sagamihara, 252-0131, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugimoto H., Pxp Corporation, Kanagawa, Sagamihara, 252-0131, Japan
Abstract: Feasibility of direct coupling between flexible perovskite/chalcopyrite tandem solar cells and all-solid-state thin-film batteries was numerically investigated for vehicle integrated photovoltaic (VIPV) applications installed on the roof of vehicles under realistic outdoor conditions. In the case of no-load connection, the power coupling efficiency (PC_Eff) between the solar cells and the batteries showed considerably high Eff above 96% during whole daytime from spring to winter with the condition of the state of charge (SOC) less than 75%. Then, the PC_Eff gradually decreased as the SOC was approaching full charge, which was considered to be beneficial feature for preventing over charge. In the case of appropriate load connection with sufficiently charged batteries, the PC_Eff reached over 99% during whole daytime from spring to winter by the self-tuning functions of the directly integrated devices with the solar cells and the batteries. These results indicated possibility for simple and low-cost VIPV applications without any power conditioners and bypass diodes as well as extra sub-batteries.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Kabra R.
Author full names: Kabra, Raunak (58850375300)
Title: Reliability Availability and Maintainability Study for Concentrated Solar Plants and How to Account for Current Limitations and Challenges
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Risktec Solutions Dmcc, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Kabra R., Risktec Solutions Dmcc, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Sunlight is an abundant resource, nothing else across the renewables spectrum generates such high expectations for investment as the potential of directly harnessing the power of the sun. Designers and operators are carrying out reliability studies essentially to optimize project profitability as a function of income and expense factors such as capital expenditures, operating expenditures, production rate, the frequency of equipment failures and the associated downtime for such failures. Reliability Availability and Maintainability (RAM) studies are used to predict system availability, identify ways to improve system availability, throughput performance and the efficiency of solar plant from a cost/benefit point of view. The models generated require data to predict capacity as in uptime or revenue profile forward. Reliability expressed in Mean Time Between Failures and Maintainability expressed as the average time to return failed item to service (Mean Time to Repair) are based on rule sets and assumptions for different technologies. Component data is provided by the suppliers (e.g. laboratory testing/inspection), rather than years of operational excellence, as the industry is not as mature as conventional power plants. The sun's intermittency of power output affects the investment requirements to distinguish between installed capacity and electricity actually generated due to unpredictable nature of solar radiations. Tower-based Concentrated Solar Plants (CSP) holds out the advantages of thermal energy storage while the solar field is available only during the day. These constraints needs to be adequately captured in the analysis in order to assess the reliability and energy contribution of the solar system to meet overall system demand. A particular case study is presented for a CSP facility.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Alhammadi N.; Alantali M.; Rodriguez-Ubinas E.
Author full names: Alhammadi, Noura (57220929891); Alantali, Mohamed (57220927747); Rodriguez-Ubinas, Edwin (55173603700)
Title: Crystalline Silicon Solar PV Integration in Residential Buildings: Case Studies From Solar Decathlon Middle East
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Alhammadi N., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alantali M., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Rodriguez-Ubinas E., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The integration of crystalline silicon solar PV modules in the built environment holds immense potential for sustainable development in the Middle East. Optimizing PV performance, however, in the hot and harsh climate presents several challenges. Through the Solar Decathlon Middle East competitions, international university teams demonstrated innovative approaches to enhance the performance of building-integrated c-Si PV systems in the region. This paper investigates the PV systems and unique strategies adopted by the teams to boost energy performance, considering approaches like passive and active cooling, bifacial PV integration, and tracking systems. Besides their key role, implementing these advances can lead to additional benefits such as energy and cost savings.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Riad M.; Chapaneri K.; Rodriguez-Ubinas E.; John J.J.; Mathiak G.
Author full names: Riad, Micheal (58850688100); Chapaneri, Kaushal (58822140600); Rodriguez-Ubinas, Edwin (55173603700); John, Jim Joseph (56073475100); Mathiak, Gerhard (57277706300)
Title: Temperature and Energy Yield Study of Façade Building Integrated PV Modules in Hot Desert Region
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mrfs Power Building Contracting, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Riad M., Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Mrfs Power Building Contracting, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Chapaneri K., Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Rodriguez-Ubinas E., Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; John J.J., Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mathiak G., Research and Development Center, Dewa, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: In this study, a comparative analysis was conducted for building integrated PV (BIPV) modules. The DEWA BIPV Cube, installed in 2017, is an example of applying passive cooling techniques in BIPV. It features a double-skin facade that allows natural ventilation conditions for the back side of PV modules. Temperature and energy yield were measured continuously on two different module types, crystalline Si (C-Si) and Cu(In, Ga)(Se, S)2 (CIGS). C-Si modules have lower module operating temperatures than CIGS modules. The maximum temperature for both types was slightly above 70°C (Level 1 of IEC TS 63126). C-Si modules still obtain higher energy yields, although C-Si has a higher temperature coefficient. The results of this study indicate that C-Si modules have lower power degradation rates in facades with about l%/year, while CIGS modules degrade up to three times faster than C-Si modules.  © 2023 IEEE.

Author full names: Dehghani, Soroush (58850317000); Daon, Udi (58850472100); Shariatzadeh, Mohammadjavad (58850704000)
Title: Propelling a Paradigm Shift: Revolutionizing Energy Yield in Solar Photovoltaic Systems
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Daanaa Resolution Inc., Vancouver, V6A lA4, BC, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dehghani S., Daanaa Resolution Inc., Vancouver, V6A lA4, BC, Canada; Daon U., Daanaa Resolution Inc., Vancouver, V6A lA4, BC, Canada; Shariatzadeh M., Daanaa Resolution Inc., Vancouver, V6A lA4, BC, Canada
Abstract: An innovative embedded power electronics solution that increases energy production by as much as 70% via mitigating losses caused by shading from light obstructions has been proposed. This technology also addresses the downstream impacts of PV module shading on the efficiency and the clipping in conventional inverters. This solution delivers DC optimization and DC to AC conversion at a module substring level that significantly improves energy production, simplifying installation and maintenance, and improving reliability.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Saleh N.; Rosati S.; Sharawi A.; Wahed M.A.; Balestra G.
Author full names: Saleh, Neven (37059616600); Rosati, Samanta (36490087000); Sharawi, Amr (6507881182); Wahed, Manal Abdel (8245370900); Balestra, Gabriella (6701479637)
Title: Application of quality function deployment and genetic algorithm for replacement of medical equipment
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Electronics and Telecommunication Department, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Saleh N., Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt, Electronics and Telecommunication Department, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Rosati S., Electronics and Telecommunication Department, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy; Sharawi A., Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Wahed M.A., Biomedical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Balestra G., Electronics and Telecommunication Department, Politecnico di Torino, Torino, Italy
Abstract: The management of medical equipment raises a range of complex problems including those associated with replacement processes. One of the most significant challenges is to identify a proper list of medical equipment that requires replacement and then to optimize this list. In this article, we present a new approach to solve this problem by integrating Quality Function Deployment (QFD) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) in one framework. In a previous application, QFD has proven its validity to solve the priority problem; meanwhile GA is an optimization method. Hence, the proposed model, QFD-GA, was developed to prioritize the medical equipment for replacement process taking into account a set of criteria; in addition, the prioritized list is optimized according to the available budget of the hospital to maximize the number of replaced devices. The validation of the proposed model was carried out on sixty devices that include different types of medical equipment in one public hospital. Results show that the proposed model can efficiently classify the priority into four subcategories, and simultaneously maximize the number of medical equipment to be replaced considering the budget constraint. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: genetic algorithms; medical equipment; priority; quality function deployment; replacement

Title: Applications of In-Situ Module I-V Measurement for PV System Performance Monitoring & Control
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Atonometrics, Austin, 78757, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gostein M., Atonometrics, Austin, 78757, TX, United States; Stueve B., Atonometrics, Austin, 78757, TX, United States
Abstract: New measurement devices are available that provide the ability to continuously measure current-voltage (I-V) curves and associated parameters on individual modules in-situ within a PV plant. This opens the possibility for many new monitoring applications with increased resolution into PV module performance. Here we review the technology of in-situ I-V measurement and discuss potential applications.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Irshad S.; Salman M.; Akram M.U.; Yasin U.
Author full names: Irshad, Samra (56522975400); Salman, Muhammad (57205092820); Akram, M. Usman (24474159700); Yasin, Ubaidullah (56023241200)
Title: Automated detection of Cotton Wool Spots for the diagnosis of Hypertensive Retinopathy
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, College of e and Me, National University of Sciences and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Department of Computer Engineering, College of e and Me, National University of Sciences and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Department of Ophthalmology, Armed Forces Institute of Ophthalmology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Irshad S., Department of Electrical Engineering, College of e and Me, National University of Sciences and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Salman M., Department of Electrical Engineering, College of e and Me, National University of Sciences and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Akram M.U., Department of Computer Engineering, College of e and Me, National University of Sciences and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan; Yasin U., Department of Ophthalmology, Armed Forces Institute of Ophthalmology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan
Abstract: The development of automated systems for the detection and diagnosis of different diseases are quite popular now-a-days. Hypertensive Retinopathy (HR) is an eye disease caused by high blood pressure. Formation of Cotton Wool Spots (CWS) is one of the important clinical signs that are seen at advanced stages in HR. An automated system is presented in this paper for the detection of Cotton Wool Spots in digital retinal images. The system first enhances candidate regions using Gabor filter bank, then binarize those regions using Global thresholding. The proposed system is tested on a locally gather fundus image dataset, and achieved 82.21% and 82.38% sensitivity and PPV, respectively. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Seddik N.; Youssef S.; Kholief M.
Author full names: Seddik, Noha (56523182900); Youssef, Sherine (56221489000); Kholief, Mohamed (6602356086)
Title: Automatic seizure detection in long-term scalp EEG using Weighted Permutation Entropy and Support Vector Machine
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Computer Department-College of Engineering, Arab Academy for Science and Technology (AAST), Alexandria, Egypt; College of Computer Science and Information Technology, Arab Academy for Science and Technology (AAST), Alexandria, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Seddik N., Computer Department-College of Engineering, Arab Academy for Science and Technology (AAST), Alexandria, Egypt; Youssef S., Computer Department-College of Engineering, Arab Academy for Science and Technology (AAST), Alexandria, Egypt; Kholief M., College of Computer Science and Information Technology, Arab Academy for Science and Technology (AAST), Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: The automated epileptic seizure detection has emerged as an important field in the recent years; this involves analyzing the Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals instead of the traditional visual inspection performed by expert neurologists. In this paper, a model has been introduced that integrates Weighted Permutation Entropy (WPE) as input feature to a Support Vector Machine (SVM) learning model to enhance the sensitivity and precision of the detection process. WPE is a modified statistical parameter of the permutation entropy (PE) that measures the complexity and irregularity of a time series. It incorporates both the mapped ordinal pattern of the time series and the information contained in the amplitude of its sample points. The proposed system utilizes the fact that entropy based measures for the EEG segments during epileptic seizure are lower than in normal EEG. Experiments have been conducted to demonstrate the sensitivity and precision of the proposed model. Results showed that the model can considerably discriminate between EEG brain signal into seizure and no-seizure classes. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Electroencephalogram (EEG); Epileptic Seizure Detection; Support Vector Machine (SVM); Weighted Permutation Entropy (WPE)

Author full names: Elsayed, Mohamed (57207503299); El-Sherry, Taymour (35217850200); Abdelgawad, Mohamed (6508318697)
Title: Development of Computer Assisted Sperm Analysis (CASA) plugin for analyzing sperm in microfluidic environments using Image-J
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Elsayed M., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; El-Sherry T., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdelgawad M., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Abstract: We modified a previously reported Computer Assisted Sperm Analysis (CASA) plugin for Image-J to enable analyzing sperm cells in microfluidic environments. An image processing pipeline was built for object detection and particle tracking was improved. New parameters were introduced to allow studying new aspects of sperm motion behavior such as rheotaxis and wall tracking. A preliminary study using this tool agreed well with previously reported studies on rheotaxis and wall tracking behavior of sperm. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Abdellah M.; Eldeib A.; Sharawi A.
Author full names: Abdellah, Marwan (56432915800); Eldeib, Ayman (6507588870); Sharawi, Amr (6507881182)
Title: Offline large scale fourier volume rendering on low-end hardware
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Abdellah M., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt; Eldeib A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt; Sharawi A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt
Abstract: The resolution of medical data sets acquired by state-of-the-art imaging modalities is growing rapidly. Providing high-end workstations to visualize such data sets might not be affordable in some cases. To resolve this issue, there should be alternative convenient software solutions to handle huge data sets either by out-of-core or offline rendering applications. This presented work features an offline rendering pipeline that is capable of rendering digital x-ray radiographs of very large scale volumetric data sets, which cannot fit into the memory of the running platform relying on spatial-domain decomposition and projection-slice theorem. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Makram A.W.; Khalifa A.M.; El-Wakad M.T.; El-Rewaidy H.; Fahmy A.S.; Ibrahim E.-S.H.
Author full names: Makram, Abram W. (56523300600); Khalifa, Ayman M. (7101772509); El-Wakad, Mohamed. T. (26867587000); El-Rewaidy, Hossam (56165295300); Fahmy, Ahmed S. (7004440552); Ibrahim, El-Sayed H. (8346344500)
Title: Evaluation of cardiac left ventricular mass from Tagged Magnetic Resonance Imaging
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; University of Michigan Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Makram A.W., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; Khalifa A.M., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; El-Wakad M.T., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; El-Rewaidy H., Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Fahmy A.S., Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Ibrahim E.-S.H., University of Michigan Ann Arbor, MI, United States
Abstract: Tagged Magnetic Resonance Imaging (tMRI) is considered the gold standard for quantitative assessment of the cardiac regional function. However, quantification of the global function from tMRI is challenging due to the low contrast between myocardium and blood in these images, and hence, prevents the accurate segmentation of the myocardium. In this work, a method for enhancing the myocardium-to-blood contrast in tagged MR images is presented. First, the tag pattern in tMRI is removed by accurately suppressing the frequency components of the tag pattern to produce tagless images. Then, the image contrast is enhanced by estimating the local standard deviation and using it to suppress the blood signal intensity. The proposed method is applied on a dataset for 12 patients to calculate the global cardiac functional parameters. The results are then compared to those calculated from standard cine MRI image sequences of the same patients. The results show that the proposed method can be used to accurately estimate the left ventricular volume and mass. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Global function estimation; Left Ventricular Segmentation; Tag removal; Tagged MRI
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Blood; Image enhancement; Image segmentation; Functional parameters; Global functions; Left ventricular; Left ventricular mass; Local standard deviation; Quantitative assessments; Tag removal; Tagged MRI; Magnetic resonance imaging

Title: Performance Analysis of Building Integrated Photovoltaic (BIPV): MANOVA Analysis
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Industrial Engineering, Engineering Systems Management Program, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates; College of Arts and Sciences, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Alzahmi W., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Industrial Engineering, Engineering Systems Management Program, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates; Alyaarbi A., American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Industrial Engineering, Engineering Systems Management Program, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates; Alnaqbi T., American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Industrial Engineering, Engineering Systems Management Program, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates; Alzaatreh A., College of Arts and Sciences, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Department of Mathematics and Statistics, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Global energy consumption has increased over the years due to population growth, economic expansion, and the pursuit of a higher quality of life. The building sector is a critical sector for high consumption, contributing to about 36% of the total global energy consumption in 2020. The global interest in reducing energy consumption allows different sectors to adopt renewable resources such as solar photovoltaics (PV). However, utilizing solar PV in buildings has limitations due to rooftop space constraints in newly designed buildings. Due to this limitation and continuous innovation in solar PV technologies, Building Integrated Photovoltaics (BIPV) have been introduced as a potential alternative for solar PV in buildings. As such, BIPV energy performance and panel temperatures are affected by many factors such as orientation setup and technology type. Therefore, this research aims to analyze the impact of technology type (indium gallium selenide (CIGS) and monocrystalline (MONO) & orientation on BIPV energy production & module temperature. The data used for this study is based on a project completed in Dubai for BIPV in building applications. The results indicate that BIPV type and system orientation during each session significantly affect BIPV energy production and BIPV module temperature.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Qureshi A.N.
Author full names: Qureshi, Adnan N. (57197854424)
Title: A framework for segmentation and estimation of intracranial measurements in CT scans
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: University of Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Qureshi A.N., University of Bedfordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Inter-observer variability in assessment of medical images is considered 'Achilles heel' amongst radiologists because it can lead to missed diagnoses and grave consequences. Measurements on neuro-images to ascertain severity and extent of the pathology or trauma are routinely performed, however, poor perception, inaccurate deduction, incomplete knowledge or the quality of the image can affect the intuition of the doctor leading to errors and variation. In this paper we present a novel, hybrid technique for segmentation of significant anatomical landmarks using template matching, artificial neural networks and level sets, and estimation of various ratios and indices as well as haematoma volume on brain CT scans. The proposed method is efficient and robust in segmenting cross-sectional, noncontrast CT scans and has been evaluated on images from subjects with different ages and both genders. The proposed method has an average ICC ≥ 0.97 and Jaccard Index ≥ 0.86 compared with the experts. Hence, our approach can be used in processing data for further use in research and clinical environment to provide second opinions very close to the experts' intuition. © 2014 IEEE.

Title: Identification of Micro-Defects in Solar Cells using Electroluminescence Images via Hybrid Approach
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Manandhar P., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates; Rafiq H., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates; Kumar S., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates; Qureshi O.A., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates; Rodriguez-Ubinas E., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, 564, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Renewable energy resources can play an important role in significantly offsetting the power demand in most of the world. Being the lowest-cost renewable resource, investment in photovoltaic solar can be prioritized if the reliability of continuous generation is guaranteed. Micro defects in PV cells can reduce the electrical output and if not detected can lead to large-scale power distributions. Therefore, electroluminescence (EL) image is commonly used these days to detect these micro defects and classify the various types of these defects. Hence, a hybrid approach consisting of Alibi detection algorithm is proposed, which makes use of a deep learning-based approach to detect abnormal solar cells. And decision tree is employed for the previously obtained outlier instance score to further classify it into the different kinds of defects present in the EL image of the solar cells. The proposed model is tested on the ELPV image dataset consisting of mono conventional crystalline silicon cells with above 97% accuracy.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Mousa M.A.; Almansoori A.N.; Alajami F.A.
Author full names: Mousa, Maha Ali (58850305000); Almansoori, Afra Nasser (58085059600); Alajami, Fatima Ahmed (58850691600)
Title: A Hybrid PV Power Forecasting Model Implementing Emerging Machine Learning Algorithms: Prophet and Neural Prophet
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Rochester Institute of Technology, Department of Graduate Programs and Research, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Mousa M.A., Rochester Institute of Technology, Department of Graduate Programs and Research, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Almansoori A.N., Rochester Institute of Technology, Department of Graduate Programs and Research, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alajami F.A., Rochester Institute of Technology, Department of Graduate Programs and Research, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: To limit the dependency on non-regenerative energy, power utilities around the world are actively integrating photovoltaic technologies with existing electrical grids. Through this integration, a new generation profile is introduced to the existing supply profile, which imbalances the supply-demand of electric loads. Another noteworthy constraint is the dependency of the PV power generation on intermittent meteorological conditions, which profoundly impacts the continuity and quality of the generation. To address the raised constraints, the electricity generation profile demands thorough analysis to ensure stability of electrical grids. From this perspective, this paper proposes forecasting the PV power output for a short-term duration to overcome the constraints. Seven years (2014-2020) of historical data for a power plant in the United Arab Emirates were used to generate the forecasts. A hybrid forecasting approach was implemented, combining the emerging machine learning algorithms Prophet and Neural Prophet. Three univariate meteorological submodels (temperature, global irradiance, humidity) were built individually using the Neural Prophet algorithm. The power forecasting model was built using the Prophet algorithm, which utilized the meteorological forecasts and historical power readings. The results of the forecasts indicated good performance compared to the individual Prophet model.  © 2023 IEEE.

Title: Photoresponse of Thermally Evaporated Copper Oxide-Based Solar Cells
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Sharjah, Sustainable Energy & Power Systems Research Centre, Sustainable and Renewable Energy, Engineering Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; American University of Sharjah, Materials Science and Engineering PhD Program, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; American University of Sharjah, Mechancial Engineering Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; University of Sharjah, Sustainable Energy & Power Systems, Research Centre, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; University of Sharjah, Industrial Engineering and Engineering, Management Department, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates

Abstract: This study reports on the fabrication and characterization of a copper oxide (CuO)-based photoactive cell. Copper was thermally evaporated onto two substrates and post-treated using chemical and thermal treatments to obtain different semiconducting types of CuO. Absorption measurements were conducted to obtain the bandgaps of CuO, which were found to be 1.51 eV and 1.21 eV, for the chemically and thermally treated CuO, respectively. Finally, a chronoamperometry test was conducted to confirm the photoresponse of the cell, which showed a doubling of output current values under light conditions compared to dark conditions.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Roshen W.
Author full names: Roshen, Waseem (56624709000)
Title: Load Independent, Enhanced Power Extraction from a Solar Cell: Modifying the Output Characteristics of a Solar Cell Externally
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Ss Power Technology, Hilliard, 43026, OH, United States; The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roshen W., Ss Power Technology, Hilliard, 43026, OH, United States, The Ohio State University, Columbus, 43210, OH, United States
Abstract: A new high frequency power extraction circuit, called PXtractor@, is described. This circuit uses electronic parameters of the solar cell. The values of these electronic parameters are derived from a physics-based circuit model of the solar cell. The power extraction circuit provides a perfect impedance match between the output side of the solar cell and the input side of the circuit. This allows the power extraction circuit to extract all the electrical power generated in the solar cell. The circuit then transfer all power to the load, irrespective of load value. Experimental results for the output power of a single cell are presented. These results show that the power delivered to a load is independent of the load value. Also, these results show that power delivered to the load can be increased many times for a large range of load values. Because of the increased output power, it is expected that further development of this technique can results in greatly reduced cost, weight, and size of the solar systems. The new technique is also applicable to solar panels as well as to other high-impedance sources of electrical energy such as fuel cells.  © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Extraction; Impedance matching (electric); Solar panels; Electronic parameters; Extraction circuits; High frequency power; Load independent; Load values; New high; Output characteristics; Output power; Power; Power extraction; Fuel cells

Author full names: Kalaghichi, Saman Sharbaf (58850306900); Preis, Pirmin (56073364600); Lossen, Jan (35503687600); Hob, Jan (58850692500); Werner, Jurgen H. (7403262884)
Title: Progress in TOPCon Cell Development and Laser Process for the Integration of Front Side Passivated Contacts
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: International Solar Energy Research Center Konstanz, Konstanz, 78467, Germany; Institute for Photovoltaics, University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, 70569, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kalaghichi S.S., International Solar Energy Research Center Konstanz, Konstanz, 78467, Germany, Institute for Photovoltaics, University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, 70569, Germany; Preis P., International Solar Energy Research Center Konstanz, Konstanz, 78467, Germany; Lossen J., International Solar Energy Research Center Konstanz, Konstanz, 78467, Germany; Hob J., International Solar Energy Research Center Konstanz, Konstanz, 78467, Germany; Werner J.H., Institute for Photovoltaics, University of Stuttgart, Stuttgart, 70569, Germany
Abstract: We report on the progress in tunnel oxide passivated contact (TOPCon) solar cell development at ISC Konstanz and on a laser process that is suited to create local p-type doped polycrystalline silicon (p+poly-Si) layers for integration into an advanced TOPCon cell with p+poly-Si passivated contacts on the front side. On the basis of ISC's TOPCon technology which we name tunnel oxide under contact (TOUCAN), we show that plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) of in-situ silicon dioxide (SiO2) and n-type doped amorphous silicon (a-Si) yields equivalent TOUCAN cell performance compared with cell based on low-pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD) deposited a-Si layers. Further, we outline ISC's road map towards advanced TOUCAN cells and present detailed results on a laser activation process to create structured p+poly-Si layers with a low saturation current density J_ 0< 10 fA/cm2 © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Amorphous silicon; Passivation; Plasma CVD; Plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition; Polycrystalline materials; Polysilicon; Silicon oxides; Cell development; Cell performance; Cell-based; Contact technologies; Development process; Laser process; P-type; Si layer; Solar cell development; Tunnel oxides; Silica

Authors: Hassanein A.S.; Khalifa A.M.; El-Wakad M.T.
Author full names: Hassanein, Azza S. (56167369800); Khalifa, Ayman M. (7101772509); El-Wakad, Mohamed T. (26867587000)
Title: Estimation of Eulerian strain from tagged MRI using Optical flow
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hassanein A.S., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; Khalifa A.M., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt; El-Wakad M.T., Biomedical Engineering Department, Helwan University, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is considered as noninvasive imaging modalities provide information on myocardial function, viability, and morphology. One of the most common MRI techniques is tagging MRI, based on this technique the deformation of the myocardium can be evaluated and some of cardiac functions can be examined. The strain of cardiac muscle one of the parameters estimated based on the estimated deformation, this estimated strain help in the examination of myocardium viability. This paper presents a mathematical model that simulates the real cardiac motion during myocardial tagging. Using this model and real data, we estimate the circumferential strain using strain tensor with Band-pass Optical flow (BPOF) technique and compare it with the estimated strain of Harmonic Phase (HARP as a golden standard technique. The results exhibit that the stain can be estimated using BPOF method with the same level of accuracy compared to HARP method, however, BPPOF provides more reliable results than HARP, with no tracking errors, at the myocardial boundaries. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: cardiac motion analysis; optical flow; tagging CMR

Authors: Mousa D.; Zayed N.; Yassine I.A.
Author full names: Mousa, Doaa (56522937000); Zayed, Nourhan (6603169793); Yassine, Inas A. (8664279000)
Title: Automatic cardiac MRI localization method
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Computers and Systems, Electronic Research Institute, Giza, Egypt; Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Mousa D., Computers and Systems, Electronic Research Institute, Giza, Egypt; Zayed N., Computers and Systems, Electronic Research Institute, Giza, Egypt; Yassine I.A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Abstract: Cardiovascular diseases remain the biggest cause of death worldwide. Early detection is the most important step to solve this problem. Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging (CMR) has shown its capability of imaging the heart and evaluation of cardiac function without exposure to ionizing radiation. In this paper, we aim to perform automatic heart localization in MRI short axis view using a simple and effective way. The proposed algorithm can be described through the following two steps: (a) preprocessing step to denoise the images using Gaussian filter, and (b) localization step based on shape recognition technique. The algorithm, implemented using MATLAB, was developed and tested using two datasets. First one consists of 33 subjects normal and abnormal for a total of 7980 2D images and the second one consists of 50 2D images related to normal subject. The results here are evaluated through the classification into three types: totally localized case (complete heart falls inside the selected ROI window), partially localized case (small part, less than 10%, of LV or RV falls outside the selected ROI window), and not localized case (more than 10% of the hearts falls outside the selected ROI window). It gives result with 91.4% accuracy for totally localized case, 8.1% for partially localized case, and 0.5% for not localized case. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Makary M.M.; Bu-Omer H.M.; Kadah Y.M.
Author full names: Makary, Meena M. (56090856900); Bu-Omer, Hani M. (56523311500); Kadah, Yasser M. (7005419513)
Title: Spectral subtraction denoising improves accuracy of Slow Cortical Potential based brain-computer interfacing
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Electrical and Computer Engineering, King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Makary M.M., Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Bu-Omer H.M., Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Kadah Y.M., Electrical and Computer Engineering, King Abdul Aziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Spectral subtraction denoising as a new preprocessing block for Slow Cortical Potential(SCP)-based brain computer interface is proposed. This method adaptively reduces the noise attached to the signal using spectral subtraction denoising. We show that this technique provides better performance when low number of electrodes is used. This suggests its potential application in portable BCI real time applications where low power and minimum weight are required for practical use. Here, the classification accuracy was used as performance measure. The developed method provides relatively better performance compared to the more commonly used wavelet shrinkage signal denoising. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Ahmed O.; Abdellah H.; Elsayed M.; Abdelgawad M.; Mousa N.A.; El-Badri N.
Author full names: Ahmed, Omnia (56522616400); Abdellah, Hassan (56523100800); Elsayed, Mohamed (57207503299); Abdelgawad, Mohamed (6508318697); Mousa, Noha A. (16042949700); El-Badri, Nagwa (6602843247)
Title: Tissue dissociation miniaturized platform for uterine stem cell isolation and culture
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Faculty of Medicine, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Mechanical Engineering Department, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Center of Excellence of Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine, Zewail City of Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed O., Faculty of Medicine, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdellah H., Mechanical Engineering Department, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Elsayed M., Mechanical Engineering Department, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdelgawad M., Mechanical Engineering Department, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Mousa N.A., Center of Excellence of Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine, Zewail City of Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt; El-Badri N., Center of Excellence of Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine, Zewail City of Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Endometrial stem cells provide a readily accessible source of adult stem cells suitable for various stem cell based therapies. The first essential step in the process of stem cell isolation, sorting and culture is tissue dissociation into single cell suspension. Tissue dissociation efficiency determines the number of resulting viable cells which in turn could affect the feasibility of the subsequent stem cell application. Microfluidic based platforms could provide several advantages over current conventional tissue dissociation techniques (e.g. mechanical or enzymatic or both) and help the optimization of the process towards a better reproducible cellular outcome. Objective: To develop a simple miniaturized platform for endometrial tissue dissociation which can be used to evaluate and optimize experimental conditions necessary for producing single cell suspension with minimal cell damage. Methods: A Poly-DiMethylSiloxane (PDMS) channel microfluidic platform was designed. The platform includes a tissue dissociation chamber where raw endometrial tissue was incubated. Trypsin was delivered through an inlet channel while another inlet enabled parallel delivery of a cell suspension medium and an outlet channel received the downstream dissociated endometrial cells. A cell size based filtration step is designed to trap large debris using two rows of posts. A viability stain is used to test the viability of cells produced at different enzyme-tissue contact durations. Conclusion: We present a simple microfluidics based platform for endometrial tissue dissociation that can be used for subsequent endometrial stem cell research applications and can be further applied to other tissues. © 2014 IEEE.

Title: PV Modules Sand and Brush Abrasion Testing
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Fraunhofer Isc, Würzburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mathiak G., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; John J.J., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Najeeb N.S., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alshanqiti H., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Sawaftah M., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Seentakath A., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Kumar S., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Gabbadi P., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Kumar Y., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alberts V., Dewa R&d Center, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mirza M., Fraunhofer Isc, Würzburg, Germany
Abstract: For the qualification and benchmarking of PV modules for hot desert operation, a test sequence for sandstorm and cleaning durability testing is introduced. A test sequence based on sand and brush abrasion testing of IEC 62788-7-3 is under evaluation using blowing sand testing, sand trickling testing, and a cleaning robot test-stand. The change in short-circuit current of PV modules, roughness, transmittance and reflectance of glass surfaces and samples are measured. Coaxial microscopy is used to describe the abrasion process of the front glass texture and the anti-reflective coating.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Mohamad C.; Jean S.
Author full names: Mohamad, Chbaro (58850769600); Jean, Salame (58850769700)
Title: Survey of Machine Learning-Based Predictions of Photovoltaic Power Outputs
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dar Al Handasah- Shair & Partner, Beirut, Lebanon
Authors with affiliations: Mohamad C., Dar Al Handasah- Shair & Partner, Beirut, Lebanon; Jean S., Dar Al Handasah- Shair & Partner, Beirut, Lebanon
Abstract: Solar Photovoltaic (PV) energy has been deployed at exponential rates since the last decade to produce power from renewable and green resources as a contribution to the causes of climate change and global warming. PV power generation is subject to very dynamic changes due to its dependence on the environment and the geography, often fluctuating erratically. The variability of PV power generation poses electric grid system stability, reliability, and planning downturns. Hence, grid operations could operate at higher levels of performance and efficiencies through adequate grid scheduling that primarily relies on accurate prediction of photovoltaic power output. Due to the paramount importance of the topic, the research community investigated several forecasting strategies that rely on numerical methods, probabilistic methods, physical models and machine learning-based (ML-based) techniques. The present paper presents a comparative review of the literature targeting ML-based algorithms for short-term PV power output prediction. A complementary case study exposes a much-needed homogeneous comparison of the state-of-the-art ML-based forecasters, trained on a dataset from the University of Liège. Model structural enhancement for the state-of-the-art is proposed and evaluated in the light of literature findings.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Dalibor T.; Stolzel M.; Elanzeery H.; Aboulfadl H.; Eraerds P.; Borowski P.; Reichel R.; Didschuns I.; Frankenberger H.
