Title: World Record Efficiency Cd-Free CIGS Modules and Their Advances for Large-Scale Production
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Avancis GmbH, Saxony, Torgau, 04860, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dalibor T., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Stolzel M., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Elanzeery H., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Aboulfadl H., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Eraerds P., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Borowski P., Avancis GmbH, Bavaria, Munich, 81739, Germany; Reichel R., Avancis GmbH, Saxony, Torgau, 04860, Germany; Didschuns I., Avancis GmbH, Saxony, Torgau, 04860, Germany; Frankenberger H., Avancis GmbH, Saxony, Torgau, 04860, Germany
Abstract: With our mid-sized Cd-free R&D modules based on the cost-efficient AVANCIS SEL-RTP absorber process we have recently breached the 20% efficiency level with an efficiency of 20.3% as independently certified by NREL. We could transfer this best value to an average value of 19.6% with standard cell width in our pilotline by introduction of a screen-printed grid process. For the scale-up and industrialization of the new champion stack we developed and manufactured a new PVD tool for the key Na-PDT process required together with the sputterd ZnOS buffer process. For the fullsize module we, thereby, achieved a mean module power of 164W with fullsize champion module power at 176W. The combined process and equipment development for CAPEX and OPEX optimization will path the way for further expansion of Cd-free CIS manufacturing capacity.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Salman Y.M.; El-Dakhakhni W.W.; Mekky W.
Author full names: Salman, Yasser M. (53870707000); El-Dakhakhni, Wael W. (12762086800); Mekky, Waleed (11240480300)
Title: Development of a high resolution human brain finite element model for restructuring Traumatic Brain Injury
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Dep. of Research and Development, Egyptian Armed Forces, Cairo, Egypt; Dep. of Biomedical Engineering, McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada; Dep. of Stress Analysis, AMEC NSS, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Salman Y.M., Dep. of Research and Development, Egyptian Armed Forces, Cairo, Egypt; El-Dakhakhni W.W., Dep. of Biomedical Engineering, McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada; Mekky W., Dep. of Stress Analysis, AMEC NSS, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: High-resolution finite element models (HRFEM) simulating human heads can be utilized to quantify Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) threshold due to a direct (e.g. impact) or an indirect (e.g. blast) dynamic shock. With the complex brain structure, for an accurate investigation of the influence of such brain injuries, accurate realistic geometrical brain structures must be developed. The objective of the current simulation study is to present the steps undertaken to generate a high resolution finite element model for human brains that will assist in studying the effects of a wide a spectrum mechanical insult to human heads. In this study, an MRI-T1 DICOM data files for healthy male head have been used for segmenting and extracting the brain structure. The segmented brain model has been meshed using tetrahedral elements with maximum size of 2 mm. This HRFEM for the brain was composed of 116,394 nodes and 607,457 elements. The model was then subjected to a simulated shock wave of 0.3 MPa peak pressure from anterior direction. This was simulated using the ConWep module available in the LSDYNA explicit finite element modeling software. Three dimensional plots of maximum pressure and maximum stress clearly demonstrated significant effects of the dynamic shock load. The generated HRFEM for the brain and the simulation results demonstrate the capability of the modeling approach in describing the brain response under shock-type loads, including those caused by blast wave. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Brain Segmentation; High-resolution Finite Element Models; Shock Loads; Traumatic Brain Injury

Authors: Dellimore K.; Smith J.; Scheffer C.
Author full names: Dellimore, Kiran (6506118484); Smith, Johan (57221186389); Scheffer, Cornie (23390215100)
Title: The influence of ventilation on chest compression force and depth during neonatal cardiopulmonary resuscitation
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Research Group, Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Department of Paediatrics and Child Health, Tygerberg Hospital and Stellenbosch University, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Dellimore K., Biomedical Engineering Research Group, Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Smith J., Department of Paediatrics and Child Health, Tygerberg Hospital and Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Scheffer C., Biomedical Engineering Research Group, Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa
Abstract: Ventilation during neonatal cardiopulmonary resuscitation (NCPR) may adversely affect chest compression (CC) quality (i.e., the delivery of consistent and sufficiently deep CC) since current guidelines recommend a 3/1 CC to ventilation ratio which is much higher than the 30/2 CC to ventilation ratio recommended for children and adults. In this study the influence of ventilation on CC performance during NCPR was investigated by measuring the CC depth and force during simulated unventilated and ventilated NCPR using an infant training manikin. The results obtained indicate that ventilation may exert a significant influence on CC performance during NCPR due to dynamic changes in chest properties (i.e., stiffness and damping) which likely occur due to the high frequency of inflation and deflation of the manikin lungs during NCPR at the 3/1 CC to ventilation ratio recommended by the guidelines. © 2014 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Cardiopulmonary resuscitation; Chest compressions; Dynamic changes; High frequency HF; Stiffness and damping; Resuscitation

Authors: Al-Sabounchi A.; Alnuaimi M.; Ashaar M.; Jaber M.; Al-Qdaimat M.; Ghodayah A.
Author full names: Al-Sabounchi, Ammar (6507533065); Alnuaimi, Mariam (57208597693); Ashaar, Muhannad (55053277800); Jaber, Mahmoud (57194942682); Al-Qdaimat, Majdi (57194949148); Ghodayah, Abdullah (57221634296)
Title: Harmonic Emissions Assessment of Distributed Photovoltaic Systems in Low Voltage Network
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Al-Sabounchi A., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alnuaimi M., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Ashaar M., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Jaber M., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Al-Qdaimat M., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Ghodayah A., Power and Water Planning, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The inherent nature of power-electronic circuits inside on-grid PV inverters of Distributed Photovoltaic installations has brought new challenges of maintaining the harmonic voltage levels throughout the network within acceptable limits. Having the harmonic currents spectrum of each inverter already certified 'individually' does not ensure the compliance of accumulated spectrums from multiple of these inverters connected in parallel. As such, the accumulated harmonic current emissions from parallel PV inverters of certain Distributed Photovoltaic installations should be assessed in terms of their impact on the harmonic voltage levels throughout the network it's connected to. This work presents a detailed investigation and analysis to simulate and assess the levels of accumulated harmonic currents from a photovoltaic system with parallel PV inverters. The work contains derivations to generate emission limits based on the installed capacity of Distributed Photovoltaic installation and background harmonic voltage levels of the network. Furthermore, additional parameters have been considered, including the line impedance, topology of the point of connection, vector sum of harmonic orders, and others. The work presents an actual case study to assess the harmonic currents and voltages of a certain installation, based on which its integration approval with the grid has been decided by the network planners/operators.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Mboup A.; Akisawa A.
Author full names: Mboup, Aissatou (57217197442); Akisawa, Atsushi (7004229089)
Title: Comparison of the Truncation Effect on the Newly Designed Multi-Profile 3D Solar Concentrators and the Conventional 3D Compound Parabolic Concentrator
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Koganei, Tokyo, 184-8588, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mboup A., Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Koganei, Tokyo, 184-8588, Japan; Akisawa A., Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Koganei, Tokyo, 184-8588, Japan
Abstract: In this study, a new design method is proposed for non-tracking 3D solar concentrators. The shape of the MultiPro-CPCs consists of multiple compound parabolic concentrator (CPC) profiles with different acceptance angles in the East-West and the North-South directions. The receiver shape of the solar concentrators proposed are respectively elliptical for the MultiPro-ECPC and rectangular for the MultiPro-RCPC. Here, in addition to their original size, the shapes are truncated at 3/4 and 1/2 of their heights. The annual energy collection performances of the truncated and non-truncated MultiPro-CPCs are compared to the one of the truncated and non-truncated conventional CPCs using ray tracing simulations. All simulations are set to Tokyo and the shapes are 75° tilted from the horizontal. It was found that among the simulated designs, the MultiPro-ECPCs generally collect more energy per receiver area between May 1st and August 15th. The maximum value obtained by the non truncated MultiPro-ECPC is 138 MJ/m2. The effect of the truncation is only noticeable when the concentrator height is halved. The halved concentrators have wider angular coverage which enables them to collect energy in April and September. On the other hand, the intensity of the energy collection per receiver area decreases with the truncation in the situations where the non-truncated concentrators take the highest values. Moreover, all truncated new designs show higher performance between May 1st and August 15th compared to the non-truncated conventional 3D PC. The obtained outcomes give an idea about the possibilities that the new family of MultiPro-CPCs may provide in the field of concentration when considering high-cost receivers and concentrator height limits.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Alam F.; El-Atab N.
Author full names: Alam, Fahad (57225843405); El-Atab, Nazek (55983578000)
Title: 3D Printing of Zinc Oxide Nanoparticles Embedded Transparent Sheet for Solar Panel Encapsulation and Thermal Management
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST), Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Electrical Mathematical Science and Engineering Division, Thuwal, 23955-6900, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Alam F., King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST), Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Electrical Mathematical Science and Engineering Division, Thuwal, 23955-6900, Saudi Arabia; El-Atab N., King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST), Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Electrical Mathematical Science and Engineering Division, Thuwal, 23955-6900, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: The current work demonstrates 3D printing of transparent sheets embedded with zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles for the encapsulation of solar panels for protection and thermal management. Thin transparent sheets were prepared via a vat-photopolymerization-based 3D printing technique. The optimized sheet showed >90% transparency with a UV ray preventing capability from the range of 200-400 nm. Due to blocking of UV rays from the solar spectrum, reduction in around 8°C in the temperature from the surface of the solar panel was observed when the solar panel coated with ZnO embedded resin was exposed to sunlight for 30 min as compared to the surface temperature from the reference panel with resin coating only. The demonstrated sheet would thus be promising as an encapsulant and in assisting in the thermal management of the solar panel.  © 2023 IEEE.

Title: Assessment of PV Performance-Enhancing Technologies in Desert Climate Conditions of Dubai
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Heriot-Watt University, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Haider U., Heriot-Watt University, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Qureshi O.A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Shahzad A.A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Bozdar Baloch A.A., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Rodriguez-Ubinas E., Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Dubai receives 2,200 KW/m2 of global horizontal irradiance (GHI) annually, and its desert areas have an albedo of 0.4, making it an excellent location to generate electricity through photovoltaics (PV). However, it also has extremely hot temperatures in the summer and constant dust. Therefore, this study investigated and compared several performance-enhancing technologies, installation parameters, and site conditions to produce relevant information for improving the behavior of PV plants in Dubai's urban and desert conditions. The results of simulations carried out in the System Advisor Model (SAM). For monofacial modules the energy production is increased using: ideal thermal management by 12% (fixed horizontal); single-axis east-west trackers by 34.2%; and their combination by 52.8%. Fixed-mounted bifacial modules produce 19% more than the base case of horizontally tilted monofacial modules without thermal management, and this type of module in a single-axis tracker achieved more than 54% improvement. Monofacial module mounted over dual axis tracker with thermal management showed the best increment in energy yield of all cases.  © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Landforms; Solar panels; Urban growth; Climate condition; Desert area; Desert climates; Generate electricity; Parameter conditions; Performance enhancing; Photovoltaic performance; Photovoltaics; Site conditions; Technology installation; Temperature control

Authors: Subramani A.; Senthil C.; Sarkar K.J.; Sofer Z.
Author full names: Subramani, Amutha (58850851000); Senthil, Chenrayan (56131605200); Sarkar, Kalyan Jyoti (56900759800); Sofer, Zdenek (8920398600)
Title: Electric Field Simulation of Ultrathin CuInP2S6 Solar Cells
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Czech Republic; Gyeongsang National University, Department of Energy Engineering, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Subramani A., University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Czech Republic; Senthil C., Gyeongsang National University, Department of Energy Engineering, South Korea; Sarkar K.J., University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Czech Republic; Sofer Z., University of Chemistry and Technology Prague, Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Czech Republic
Abstract: Ultrathin 2D CuInP2S6 ferroelectrics play an important role in the development of the bulk photovoltaic effect (BPVE), which might potentially be exploited for the production of third generation solar cells. Thus, it is imperative to model and simulate solar cells based on CuInP2S6 which can provide valuable insights into the underlying performance mechanism. In this study, the photovoltaic device designed using layered CuInP2S6 is studied through COMSOL Multiphysics. The results imply that the current contribution highlights the effective electrical and optical photogeneration characteristics of a CuInP2S6 solar cell. The COMSOL module constituted the 'Semiconductor Module,' and 'Wave Optics Module' to compute the electron and hole concentrations, and generation rate.  © 2023 IEEE.
Author Keywords: CuInP<sub>2</sub>S<sub>6</sub>; ferroelectrics; solar cells

Title: Impacts of Photovoltaic Modules on Residential Buildings in Dubai
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Manandhar P., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Trepci E., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Rafiq H., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Rodriguez-Ubinas E., Dewa R&d Centre, Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, P.O. Box 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Climate change and fossil fuel depletion have increased the dependency on renewable energy sources. And solar photovoltaic (PV) technology has evolved to step in to fill the gaps. Dubai, the region with abundant sunlight, has emerged as a significant player in the field of solar energy. This work aims to present the impact of PV modules in sample residential buildings of Dubai, exploring how imported energy is affected by the distributed energy in the region. The study uses empirical data from smart meters to provide valuable insights into the role of PV modules in achieving a sustainable energy future for Dubai.  © 2023 IEEE.

Title: Active Liquid Based Thermal Management of PV Modules
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dewa, Middle East, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Transmission Power, Transmission Maintenance Department, Transmission Civil Maintenance, Electro Machanical, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Alshaiba K., Dewa, Middle East, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Transmission Power, Transmission Maintenance Department, Transmission Civil Maintenance, Electro Machanical, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The world today is heading towards renewable energy and replacing fossil fuel energy and non-renewable energy, and part of renewable energy is the photovoltaic cells because it's using the sunlight as a primary energy source, and then it will convert the sunlight into electricity using a technology based on the photoelectric effect, and it's a type of inexhaustible and non-polluting energy that can be produced in installations ranging from small generators for self-consumption to large photovoltaic plants. Furthermore, the problem of photovoltaic cells is it suffers from overheating and that causes in decline in the efficiency. In our project we are trying to solve this problem by designing a heat sink that will cool down the photovoltaic cells and make it work more efficiently, so to start with our project, first did a lot of research for articles about this topic, to gather more information and know what have people done in the past to solve this problem, then we were able to come up with our requirements, after that we did a survey to gather more information form the customers and decided our final specifications, then we used MATLAB software to perform the calculation of the heat sink, after we are done with our calculation we were able to design the CAD module of our heat sink, then we tried to estimate our cost for this project to know the budget needed for this project.  © 2023 IEEE.

Author full names: Kumar, Sagarika (57203425925); Adothu, Baloji (57211644134); John, Jim Joseph (56073475100); Mathiak, Gerhard (57277706300); Jackel, Bengt (57221596193); Gottschalg, Ralph (6603674907); Alberts, Vivian (57278314200)
Title: Enhancing Durability of PV Modules in MENA Region: The Hot Desert Test Protocol
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Fraunhofer Center for Silicon Photovoltaics Csp, Otto-Eissfeldt-Str. 12, Halle (Saale), 06120, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kumar S., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Adothu B., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; John J.J., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mathiak G., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Jackel B., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Gottschalg R., Fraunhofer Center for Silicon Photovoltaics Csp, Otto-Eissfeldt-Str. 12, Halle (Saale), 06120, Germany; Alberts V., Dewa Research & Development Center, P.O.Box: 564, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: IEC 61215 type approval testing has assisted in enhancing the overall durability of PV modules, but its design is better suited for moderate climates, as most known failure modes have been observed in such conditions. The MENA region is emerging as a preferred site for GW-scale PV power plants with low solar electricity prices, where a one-size-fits-all approach to approval testing is inadequate. In the MENA region, PV modules are exposed to hot-dry or hot-humid climates, with high temperatures, low to moderate humidity, high UV irradiation, sandstorms, and high soiling rates being the key challenges. Therefore, there is a need to modify and/or add to existing tests and protocols to account for harsh desert conditions.  © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Irradiation; Solar panels; Storms; 'Dry' [; Condition; Electricity prices; Exposed to; Hot humid climate; Moderate climate; PV modules; PV Power plants; Solar electricity; Test protocols; Durability

Authors: Alzahmi W.; Ndiaye M.
Author full names: Alzahmi, Wadhah (57220752272); Ndiaye, Malick (7006670047)
Title: AHP Decision-Making Approach for Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Modules End-Of-Life (EOL) Disposition Strategies
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates; American University of Sharjah, Engineering Systems Management Program, Department of Industrial Engineering, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Alzahmi W., American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates, American University of Sharjah, Engineering Systems Management Program, Department of Industrial Engineering, United Arab Emirates; Ndiaye M., American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, Sharjah, 26666, United Arab Emirates, American University of Sharjah, Engineering Systems Management Program, Department of Industrial Engineering, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Increasing energy demands globally have accelerated the development of renewable technologies including solar photovoltaics (PV). However, this development has unavoidably led to the emergence of significant volumes PV waste considering 20-30 years life span before End of Life (EOL). The standard decision makers practices for PV EOL are disposal to the landfill, recycling, or reuse. Due to complexity of the decision environment, this study aims to analyze and rank solar PV disposition alternative using Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) based on five main criteria including environmental, economic, social, policy and legislation and technical. AHP Aggregating Individual Priorities (AIP) aggregation method was utilized to evaluate the overall perspective of all the study participant. In addition, individual stakeholder group decision was assessed individually to understand potential different EOL disposition perspective from different stakeholder group. The findings of the analysis shows that the overall ranking of the alternatives based on the main criteria is leaning toward recycling compared to other alternatives. However, there is a variation in the decision between individual stakeholder group.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Hassanein A.M.D.E.
Author full names: Hassanein, Ahmed Mohamed Dia Eldin (55329184400)
Title: A slab to reduce back-reflected clutter for the whole Ultra-WideBand range
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Systems and Information Dept, Engineering Division, National Research Centre, Dokki, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hassanein A.M.D.E., Systems and Information Dept, Engineering Division, National Research Centre, Dokki, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: In this paper, a slab is designed to reduce the reflected power (clutter) at the penetration of Ultra-WideBand waves to human skin. The clutter signal is very large and it severly reduces the quality of the received signals and so inhibits the detection of tumors inside human body. The governing equations for thickness of the slab and the allowed frequencies inside it are given. Simulations are performed to assess the benefits of adding a slab on the surface of the skin. The magnitude of the electric field across skin, slab and air media is plotted. A model of an Aluminum rod placed inside a skin-like media is designed and the improve in the quality of the received back-reflected signals is discussed. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fourier Transform; Frequency Domain Analysis; Radar Imaging; Ultra-WideBand Imaging

Authors: Cyrus M.; Bruce A.; Frolov S.; Moussouris J.
Author full names: Cyrus, Michael (24723545200); Bruce, Allan (58850344500); Frolov, Sergey (57209494393); Moussouris, John (58850344600)
Title: PV-Plus: High-Performance, Multi-Functional Skins for UAV
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Sunlight Aerospace Inc., Colorado, 81069, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cyrus M., Sunlight Aerospace Inc., Colorado, 81069, United States; Bruce A., Sunlight Aerospace Inc., Colorado, 81069, United States; Frolov S., Sunlight Aerospace Inc., Colorado, 81069, United States; Moussouris J., Sunlight Aerospace Inc., Colorado, 81069, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the feasibility of using flexible, thin-film PV modules as either a core component or, an incorporated technology in highly integrated, multi-functional, PV-Plus skins for solar-electric Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV). Such components can be designed and integrated into UAV platforms to deliver structural, weight, area, performance, reliability, manufacturability, and other mission-enabling advantages, more so than separately attached, discrete technologies on UAV platforms which have more limited benefit. The paper highlights the importance of minimizing platform mass for long-endurance solar-electric UAV and proposes that by integrating PV modules in a PV-Plus mode to perform a material/structural role in the UAV, the added mass of the PV can be offset. Building on this foundation of structurally integrated PV-Plus modules, additional passive, active or control functionality can be added with attendant advantages. Further, the paper emphasizes the benefits of multi-functional integration for various applications and identifies that flexible PV solutions, based on III-V, CIGS and a-Si, are now at a level that constitutes suitable foundational technologies. The article also identifies building blocks that are in place for developing multi-functional PV-Plus solutions for a wider range of platforms and missions.  © 2023 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Silicon compounds; Solar panels; Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV); Aerial vehicle; Core components; Flexible thin-films; Manufacturability; Multi-functional; Performance; Performance reliability; PV modules; Structural weight; Vehicle platforms; Antennas

Authors: Majid Ali Al Risi A.R.; Khamis Al-Zaabi F.H.; Salim Al Washahi A.M.; Mohammed Al-Maaini R.K.; Boddu M.K.
Author full names: Majid Ali Al Risi, Al Reem (58850456500); Khamis Al-Zaabi, Fatma Hassan (58850379400); Salim Al Washahi, Azza Marwan (58850853000); Mohammed Al-Maaini, Raqiya Khalid (58850456600); Boddu, Murali Krishna (58850853100)
Title: Advancing Solar PV Component Inspection: Early Defect Detection with UAV Based Thermal Imaging and Machine Learning
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman
Authors with affiliations: Majid Ali Al Risi A.R., College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman; Khamis Al-Zaabi F.H., College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman; Salim Al Washahi A.M., College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman; Mohammed Al-Maaini R.K., College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman; Boddu M.K., College of Engineering & Technology, University of Technology & Applied Sciences-Shinas, Engineering Department, PO Box 324,Al Aqr, Oman
Abstract: The timely detection of defects in electrical components of solar systems is of utmost importance to prevent potential catastrophic failures. This paper proposes a non-intrusive imaging system that utilizes ultraviolet technology to monitor the condition of components in small distributed generation plants. The system is designed to be mounted thermal camera on an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), enabling thermal imaging of solar panels. Subsequently, the captured images undergo various image processing techniques to extract relevant geometric and statistical features. These processed data are then analyzed using a machine learning classifier algorithm, aiming to identify areas with defects. Multiple algorithms are employed and compared to enhance and assess the accuracy of defect identification. This innovative approach, combining UAV-based thermal imaging and machine learning, presents a promising solution for early defect detection in solar PV components. It has the potential to significantly improve maintenance practices and mitigate the risks of system failures.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Obaid S.; Alhamadani H.; Alyammahi M.; Mathiak G.
Author full names: Obaid, Shaikha (58850303400); Alhamadani, Hebatalla (57221595336); Alyammahi, Mozah (57222076786); Mathiak, Gerhard (57277706300)
Title: Optical Properties of 3D-Printed Solar Panel Front Cover Using Clear Resin
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Research & Development Center, Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Obaid S., Research & Development Center, Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alhamadani H., Research & Development Center, Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Alyammahi M., Research & Development Center, Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Mathiak G., Research & Development Center, Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (DEWA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: In this paper, we investigated the optical properties of 3D-printed resin and its potential as an alternative option for solar panel front cover, as well as extending it to other applications. We 3D-printed 6 coupons (Size: 5 cm x 5 cm x 0.3cm) and developed six test procedures that differed between manual/automated sanding, level of sandpaper grits, and method of applying the polishing compound. Transmittance test was conducted across different stages of each experiment. Our results revealed that the highest transmittance achieved was 88% (procedures 2 and 4), due to polishing the coupon after each sanding process. In addition, the clarity of the surface was the highest for both procedures; clear of scratches and smooth in comparison to the other 4 test procedures. These results provide an insight into the potential of using 3D printed materials such as clear resin as an alternative option for solar panel front cover.  © 2023 IEEE.
Author Keywords: 3D printing; clear resin; components; desert conditions; front cover; photovoltaic module; solar glass

Authors: Rezk M.; Chikte R.; Aljasmi N.; Baloch A.A.B.
Author full names: Rezk, Mahmoud (57449135600); Chikte, Rufaidah (57214336507); Aljasmi, Nawal (57217634635); Baloch, Ahmer A.B. (56428885600)
Title: PV Module Classification Based on Spatial Distribution of Soiling Using Deep Learning Model
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Research and Development Centre Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Rezk M., Research and Development Centre Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Chikte R., Research and Development Centre Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Aljasmi N., Research and Development Centre Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates; Baloch A.A.B., Research and Development Centre Dubai Electricity and Water Authority, Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Soiling is the most common phenomenon, especially in desert regions, resulting in power losses and reduced reliability for PV modules. The spatial distribution of dust particles can be uniform or non-uniform, both negatively affecting the performance. However, the latter has more pronounced effects as it leads to partial shading, leading to current mismatching with reduced performance and the formation of hot spots. Hence, it is necessary to perform timely inspection of solar PV farms to detect and identify the distribution of dust. We propose a deep learning model for detecting dust levels on a PV module based on uniformity to achieve this objective. The workflow involves first segmenting the modules from the farm, followed by its individual localization, classification based on dust or no dust, and finally, classification based on uniformity of the dust deposition. The data is gathered using a drone equipped with a camera autonomously navigated using real-time kinetics (RTK). The overall accuracy of the classification model is more than 90 %. This enables a faster inspection process, which, combined with our algorithm, improves the overall efficiency and accuracy of the maintenance procedure.  © 2023 IEEE.
Author Keywords: classification; deep learning; non-uniform; soiling; spatial
Index Keywords: Deep learning; Learning systems; Solar panels; Spatial distribution; Deep learning; Dust particle; Learning models; Non-uniform; Overall accuracies; Performance; Powerloss; PV modules; Soiling; Spatial; Dust

Authors: El-Sherry T.M.; Elsayed M.; Abdelhafez H.K.; Abdelgawad M.
Author full names: El-Sherry, Taymour M. (35217850200); Elsayed, Mohamed (57207503299); Abdelhafez, Hatem K. (56419843200); Abdelgawad, Mohamed (6508318697)
Title: Characterization of rheotaxis of bull sperm using microfluidics
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: El-Sherry T.M., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Elsayed M., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdelhafez H.K., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdelgawad M., Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Abstract: We report detailed characterization of rheotaxis of bull sperm inside microchannels. Positive rheotaxis (PR) is the ability of sperm to swim against the flow. Our results show that PR is prevalent in bull sperm, which confirms rheotaxis as a strong mechanism for guiding sperm to the oocyte. Sperm can swim against secretions flowing downstream the female genital tract after coitus to reach the oocyte. We found that increasing flow velocity increases the percentage of sperm cells exhibiting PR and sperm swimming speed. PR sperm cells were found more likely to swim near channel walls, where local flow velocity is low, and cells were able to advance faster there compared with sperm at channel center. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Nazif K.N.; Nitta F.U.; Daus A.; Saraswat K.C.; Pop E.
Author full names: Nazif, Koosha Nassiri (57191645449); Nitta, Frederick U. (57225213564); Daus, Alwin (56736320000); Saraswat, Krishna C. (35507936600); Pop, Eric (7006671299)
Title: Performance Limits of Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Solar Cells
Source title: 2023 Middle East and North Africa Solar Conference, MENA-SC 2023 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Rwth Aachen University, Aachen, 52074, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Nazif K.N., Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Nitta F.U., Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Daus A., Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States, Rwth Aachen University, Aachen, 52074, Germany; Saraswat K.C., Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Pop E., Stanford University, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Abstract: Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) exhibit promising optoelectronic properties for use as absorber material in high-specific-power photovoltaics, including their high optical absorption coefficients, desirable band gaps, and self-passivated surfaces. The ultimate performance limit of TMD solar cells is therefore of interest. In this study, we determine the power conversion efficiency limit of multilayer MoS2, MoSe2, WS2, and WSe2 solar cells under AM 1.5 G illumination as a function of thickness and material quality. We use an extended version of the detailed balance method which includes Auger and Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) recombinations in addition to radiative losses, calculated from measured optical absorption spectra. We demonstrate that ultrathin TMD solar cells (as thin as 50 nm) can in practice achieve up to 25% power conversion efficiency with their current-stage material quality, already making them an excellent choice for high-specific-power photovoltaic applications.  © 2023 IEEE.

Authors: Sheha M.A.; Sharwy A.; Mabrouk M.S.
Author full names: Sheha, Mariam Ahmed (56523081900); Sharwy, Amr (56523229600); Mabrouk, Mai S. (36701666000)
Title: Pigmented skin lesion diagnosis using geometric and chromatic features
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical and System Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Biomedical Engineering Dept., MUST University, 6 of October, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Sheha M.A., Biomedical and System Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Sharwy A., Biomedical and System Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Mabrouk M.S., Biomedical Engineering Dept., MUST University, 6 of October, Egypt
Abstract: Skin cancer appears to be one of the most dangerous types among others by the presence of malignant melanoma as one of pigmented skin lesion forms. Automated system for the purpose of pigmented skin lesion diagnosis mentioned through that paper is recommended as a non-invasive diagnosis tool. To obviate the problem of qualitative interpretation, two different image sets are used to examine the proposed system, a set of images acquired by standard camera (clinical images) and another set of dermoscopic images captured from the magnified dermoscope. Images are enhanced and segmented to separate the lesion from the background. Different geometric and chromatic features are extracted from the region of interest resulting from segmentation process. Then, the most prominent features that can cause an effect are selected by different selection methods; which are the Fisher score ranking and the t-test method. Most prominent features were introduced to two different classifiers; artificial neural network and Support vector machine for the discrimination of the two groups of lesions. System performance was measured regarding Specificity, Sensitivity and Accuracy. The artificial neural network designed with the combined geometric and chromatic features selected by fisher score ranking enabled a diagnostic accuracy of 95% for dermoscopic and 93.75% for clinical images. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Hamdi M.M.; Awad M.I.; Abdelhameed M.M.; Tolbah F.A.
Author full names: Hamdi, Mohammed M. (56257528400); Awad, Mohammed I. (56410514600); Abdelhameed, Magdy M. (6602195381); Tolbah, Farid A. (7801421290)
Title: Lower limb motion tracking using IMU sensor network
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Mechatronics Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hamdi M.M., Mechatronics Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt; Awad M.I., Mechatronics Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt; Abdelhameed M.M., Mechatronics Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt; Tolbah F.A., Mechatronics Department, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: A motion capture system was constructed with 7- Inertial Measurement Units (IMU) covering the lower limb segments, with a wireless connection to a PC for data logging. IMU units were used to measure the lower limb segment's angular velocity and linear acceleration as direct biomechanical variables. Meanwhile, Lower Limb joints and segments inclination, in the sagittal plane, were calculated indirectly, using IMUs' direct outputs. The outputs undergo several signal conditioning phases to remove noises and bias. Furthermore, misalignment effect on the raw data is removed by an on-body calibration of the sensors. Finally, for activity recognition purposes, T-test is used to prove that capturing motion along only one side of the lower limb is sufficient, due to redundancy in the corresponding features of the biomechanical signals (variables) of each leg. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: IMU Sensor Network; Lower Limb Gait Analysis
Index Keywords: Biomechanics; Biomedical engineering; Sensor networks; Activity recognition; Inertial measurement unit; Linear accelerations; Lower limb; Lower-limb motion; Misalignment effects; Motion capture system; Wireless connection; Motion analysis

Authors: Abdelfadeel M.A.; Elshehaby S.; Abougabal M.S.
Author full names: Abdelfadeel, Mohammed A. (36805602200); Elshehaby, Saleh (55481950800); Abougabal, Mohammed S. (6602120011)
Title: Automatic segmentation of left ventricle in cardiac MRI using Maximally Stable Extremal Regions
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Biomedical Engineering Department, Medical Research Institute, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt; Computer and Systems Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Abdelfadeel M.A., Biomedical Engineering Department, Medical Research Institute, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt; Elshehaby S., Biomedical Engineering Department, Medical Research Institute, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt; Abougabal M.S., Computer and Systems Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt
Abstract: Short-axis Cine Cardiac Magnetic Resonance Images (MRI) provide a good contrast between left ventricle (LV) blood pool and myocardium. Thus, they are suitable for segmenting left ventricle cavity and computing left ventricle areas, volumes and some important clinical parameters like ejection fraction and myocardial mass. Many recent endocardium segmentation methods utilize optimal thresholding as simple and fast technique to segment left ventricle cavity. Unfortunately, intensity inhomogeneity decreases the efficiency of optimal thresholding. In this paper, we propose an automatic technique to overcome the aforementioned problems. The proposed technique is based mainly on Maximally Stable Extremal Regions (MSER) detector. The proposed technique consists of two main steps: First, generating of MSERs and Second, these regions were analyzed to select the region representing the LV cavity. The proposed technique was validated using 15 test sets from MICCAI 2009 LV segmentation challenge. Results were compared with thresholding-based method applied to the same dataset. Results show better performance in terms of segmentation accuracy and computation time. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: cardiac MRI; image segmentation; MSER
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Magnetic resonance; Magnetic resonance imaging; Automatic segmentations; Cardiac magnetic resonance images; Cardiac MRI; Intensity inhomogeneity; Left ventricle cavity; Maximally Stable Extremal Regions; MSER; Thresholding-based methods; Image segmentation

Author full names: Prauzek, Michal (35303390800); Hlavica, Jakub (56523271500); Michalikova, Marketa (56364030000); Jirka, Jakub (36548410600)
Title: Fuzzy clustering method for large metabolic data set by statistical approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Department of Cybernetics and Biomedical Engineering, Ostrava, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Prauzek M., VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Department of Cybernetics and Biomedical Engineering, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Hlavica J., VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Department of Cybernetics and Biomedical Engineering, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Michalikova M., VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Department of Cybernetics and Biomedical Engineering, Ostrava, Czech Republic; Jirka J., VSB - Technical University of Ostrava, Department of Cybernetics and Biomedical Engineering, Ostrava, Czech Republic
Abstract: This paper deals with the clustering of metabolism typology based on the energometry tests analysis. Three patients' data sources are used in this work. Large data set of respiratory quotient measurements and calculated food utilization indicators are used for analysis, along with the data obtained by the biochemical analysis of blood and insulin tests. Lastly, data set comprising bioimpedance measurements and patients' description is utilized. The fuzzy statistical method, Principal component analysis and standard data normalization methods are applied in this paper. The results are subsequently tested and medically evaluated and new research methods are described in conclusion. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Abdellah M.; Eldeib A.; Sharawi A.
Author full names: Abdellah, Marwan (56432915800); Eldeib, Ayman (6507588870); Sharawi, Amr (6507881182)
Title: MATLAB-based fourier volume rendering framework
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Abdellah M., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt; Eldeib A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt; Sharawi A., Systems and Biomedical Engineering Department, Cairo University, Egypt
Abstract: Volume rendering plays a significant role in medical imaging. It allows exploring the internal structures of volumetric data acquired by the different imaging modalities. This exploration allows accurate diagnosis and consequently effective treatment. Various volume rendering techniques exists. However, compared to other techniques, Fourier volume rendering has gained a wide acceptance by the radiologists for several reasons. This technique generates attenuation renderings similar to x-ray radiographs that are well interpreted by the physicians. Additionally, it works with time complexity of O(N2logN), and thus, it delivers interactive frame rates for large scale medical volumes in comparison with spatial-domain rendering techniques. The complexity associated with developing a basic rendering pipeline for this technique hinders medical imaging scientists from focusing their research on investigating new algorithms for improving the reconstruction quality of the resulting digital radiographs. In this paper, we present a flexible, extensible and semi-interactive high-level MATLAB-based framework for the Fourier volume rendering pipeline. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Elson W.; Scheffer C.; Dellimore K.H.; Fourie P.R.; Coetzee A.R.
Title: Development of an intravenous oxygenator using microbubbles
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Department of Anaesthesiology and Critical Care, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Stellenbosch, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Elson W., Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Scheffer C., Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Dellimore K.H., Department of Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, Stellenbosch University, South Africa; Fourie P.R., Department of Anaesthesiology and Critical Care, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Stellenbosch, South Africa; Coetzee A.R., Department of Anaesthesiology and Critical Care, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Stellenbosch, South Africa
Abstract: Patients in critical care with lung injuries require oxygenation, but current methods are not applicable for all situations. The most common method, Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation is an expensive procedure and requires highly trained staff. Respiratory Assist Catheters (RACs) could be used as an alternative because they do not place extra stress on the lungs, are easy to implement, cost-effective and are available for immediate use in clinical settings or in first aid situations. This paper describes experiments and simulations to evaluate the feasibility of intravenously oxygenating the blood using microbubbles. The tests included in vivo and ex vivo tests using animal models to investigate both the dissolution times of the microbubbles as well as the physiological effects of an intravenously placed device. Numerical simulations based on the dissolution rate of oxygen in venous blood were also completed. The results indicate that the dissolution times for the micro bubbles are too slow for the device to be successful in clinical practice. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: dissolution; intravenous; microbubble; oxygenation

Authors: Shaker M.S.; Wael M.; Yassine I.A.; Fahmy A.S.
Author full names: Shaker, Mahmoud S. (57197349575); Wael, Mai (55635503700); Yassine, Inas A. (8664279000); Fahmy, Ahmed S. (7004440552)
Title: Cardiac MRI view classification using autoencoder
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Giza, Egypt; Diagnosoft Inc, Cairo, Egypt; Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Shaker M.S., Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Giza, Egypt; Wael M., Diagnosoft Inc, Cairo, Egypt; Yassine I.A., Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Giza, Egypt, Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Fahmy A.S., Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Giza, Egypt, Systems and Biomedical Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Abstract: The growing interest of using cardiac Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) to assess the heart function and structure results in creating huge cardiac image databases. Due to the lack of standard meta-data description of the images, content-based classification of the cardiac images is essential to manage such databases. In particular, cardiac view classification is becoming an important stage for medical image analysis; efficient content-based retrieval as well as CAD systems. The major challenge in such classification lies in the large variability in image appearance caused by variation of patient-specific geometry, heart deformations, and disease conditions. In this work, a fully automated view classification of cardiac MRI images is presented. The method uses the autoencoder system for automatic feature extraction from a training dataset. A softmax classifier is used to determine the view from the selected features. Several autoencoder systems have been investigated in order to select the most suitable architecture for the problem. The results show that the proposed method outperforms current systems with orientation classification accuracy for Cine, SENC and Tagged MRI Imaging sequences was 96.7 %, 91.98 %, 100 % respectively. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Eldeeb S.M.; Fahmy A.S.
Author full names: Eldeeb, Safaa M. (57225275689); Fahmy, Ahmed S. (7004440552)
Title: Error analysis of fundus image registration using quadratic model transfformation
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Cairo, Egypt; Systems and Biomedical Engineering Dept., Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Eldeeb S.M., Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Cairo, Egypt; Fahmy A.S., Center for Informatics Science, Nile University, Cairo, Egypt, Systems and Biomedical Engineering Dept., Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Based registration of retinal images proved to be very successful especially for minimally overlapping images. The most commonly used transformation method uses a quadratic model to represent the geometry of the retinal surface. Although this model has been used for more than one decade, there is no literature that studies the model errors for abnormal eye geometries. In this work, we present a study of the registration errors of the quadratic model in case of diseased eyes. The study includes two basic models of the retinal surface for eyes suffering from: myopia; and retinal diseases (e.g. age related macular degeneration). In addition, real datasets of age related macular degeneration (AMD) patients have been used to quantify the registration error. The simulation results show that the average error can be as high as 13 pixels at extreme conditions of myopia and retinal diseases. For real datasets with typical disease conditions, the error was found to be 2.6 pixels. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Feature based methods; Quadratic model; Registration; Retinal images
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Errors; Image registration; Pixels; Age-related macular degeneration; Extreme conditions; Feature-based method; Quadratic modeling; Registration; Registration error; Retinal image; Transformation methods; Ophthalmology

Authors: Metwally M.K.; El-Gohary S.H.; Han S.M.; Byun K.M.; Kim T.-S.
Author full names: Metwally, Mohamed K. (36241872300); El-Gohary, Sherif H. (55446914500); Han, Seung Moo (8564174800); Byun, Kyung Min (7005770603); Kim, Tae-Seong (36072897600)
Title: Influence of the anisotropic mechanical properties of the breast cancer on photoacoustic imaging
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Cairo International Biomedical Engineering Conference, CIBEC 2014
Affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Metwally M.K., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea; El-Gohary S.H., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea; Han S.M., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea; Byun K.M., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea; Kim T.-S., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Kyung Hee University, Yongin, Gyeonggi, South Korea
Abstract: Photoacoustic imaging (PAI) is a non-invasive imaging modality that combines the absorption contrast of light with ultrasound resolution. Laser is used to deposit optical energy (i.e., optical fluence) into a target. As a result, the target temperature changes and causes thermal expansion to the target that leads to generating a PA signal. One of the important parameters that control the PA is the elasticity of the target. In general, most the PA studies and image reconstruction algorithms for PAI assumes isotropic elasticity within the target. However, it is known that certain soft tissues, like muscles and glands, are anisotropic with respect to elastic deformation. Also, observations indicate that breast tumors tend to be anisotropic. This could affect the reconstruction of PA images. In this study, we have investigated the influence of the anisotropic elasticity on PA back-propagation imaging using finite element method. The Fluence distribution was estimated by solving light propagation within a tissue model using Monte Carlo method. The results show that the object may appear in the reconstructed image about 10% larger or 12% smaller than the expected size based on the distribution of the young's modulus within the object if its anisotropic elasticity was not considered in the reconstruction algorithm. © 2014 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Anisotropic Elasticity; Finite Element Method; Monte Carlo Method; Photoacoustic Imaging
